newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Mid-Atlantic spot power firm amid natgas rise.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Mid-Atlantic spot power firm amid natgas rise.

text.p: Spot wholesale electricity prices in the U.S. Mid-Atlantic were mostly firmer Tuesday compared with Monday's level amid a rally in natural gas prices for the second day.
"Everyone is concentrating on the winter months. People are expecting a cold winter again," said a trader who deals in the Pennsylvania-New Jersey-Maryland (PJM) Interconnect pool.
During midday Tuesday, NYMEX November Henry Hub natgas gas climbed as high as $2.620, up 13.8 cents per million British thermal units following a 8.2 cent jump Monday.
Continual strength in natgas and residual fuel oil prices have piled up the replacement costs of those fuels used at fossil-fueled plants this winter, said brokers and marketers.
"People are using them as measures for winter generation costs," said the PJM trader.
Bucking today's action, PJM values for next-day delivery softened despite delayed returns of several regional nuclear power units from refueling.
Firm, peak PJM electricity for Wednesday delivery was quoted at $21.00-$22.00 a megawatt hour (MWh), down from Monday's $21.50-$22.50.
Modest power demand seemed to override concerns about short-term generation tightness, brokers and traders said.
November PJM electricity for firm, peak delivery was assessed at $23.20-$23.60, up from a quote of $22.90-$23.25.
December PJM power with similar delivery terms was discussed between $28.00 and $28.40, up from Monday's range of $27.50-$27.75.
January/February 1997 PJM deliveries were pegged at $32.00-$32.25, higher than a Monday quote of $31.25-$31.75.
First-quarter 1997 PJM electricity was valued at $29.30-$29.75, up from $29.10-$29.50 on Monday.
Second-quarter 1997 power prices in PJM was quoted at $21.80-$22.50, compared with Monday's $21.75-$21.85.
July/August 1997 PJM deliveries were still talked at $31.00-$31.35.

The 610 megawatt (MW) Oyster Creek nuclear plant in Forked River, N.J., and 1,090 MW Susquehanna 1 nuclear unit in Berwick, Pa., were expected to resume operation some time Wednesday. Both generating stations were scheduled to return to service this past week.
Moreover, Virginia Power Co's 909 MW North Anna 2 nuclear plant in Mineral, Va., was shut Monday to repair a small leak in a high-pressure steam line, and would resume service later this week.
